subject: Re: [junit] Using the Reflection API for private methods?  Package access?
msgSnippet: ... There is debate on this. I feel that it is best to test classes through a public interface. Others believe that this leads to adding methods only for
messageBody:
>So said javainsel on 4/13/2003 --------------------
>1. We separate the test cases in an own package. Is that best
>practice?

There is debate on this. I feel that it is best to test classes through a public interface. Others believe that this leads to adding methods "only for testing". To me, that generally means that a design change is required. I use the restrictions it places on me to improve my design.

>2. When doing this, some methods with default (package) visiblilty
>cannot be accessed. But when using the Reflection API, this methods
>can be accessed. Is it okay to use the reflection? Or is it bad
>style?

I consider it bad style to do so. I only test through public interfaces. If I need to make an interface element "only for testing", then I look for the necessary design change.

>3. What about testing private methods? It is normally not possible
>if the test is in an own class. But again I can use the reflection
>to acess private methods. Should I do that? Or should I only test
>methods with public access?

If a private method might break, then that method is doing some useful, complex work. If it is so useful and complex, then that work belongs on a different object/class. In that case, the resulting change to the interface makes it public.

I don't use package-level visibility, even though perhaps I could.

If you have many private methods in a class, then those private methods are really a smaller class trying to get out of the larger class. This is my experience.

>Maybe this question has been asked. But I have problems
>understanding the nature of the search results in this forum.

It is healthy to discuss them every so often.
